security: The memo regarding COINTELPRO reveals internal discussions on whether to furnish a report to the Senate Select Committee, potentially exposing sensitive Bureau operations. Quoting from the memo: '...objections were presented by the Bureau representatives that the report should not be furnished to the Committee, and its enclosures, particularly the legal memoranda should not be made available...' Disclosing such discussions could compromise the Bureau's ability to protect its investigative methods.
summary: This file contains memoranda and airtels related to the FBI's responses to requests from Congressional committees, including the Senate Select Committee on Intelligence Activities, and details on providing information about COINTELPRO and an informant within the New Orleans Legal Assistance Corps.
summary_one_paragraph: This collection of documents primarily concerns the FBI's interactions with various Congressional committees in 1975. It includes a memorandum detailing a decision by the Deputy Attorney General to provide a Senate Select Committee with access to a report on COINTELPRO, along with an analysis of potential damage from its disclosure. The file also contains correspondence regarding an FBI informant, Rudolph Leamer Muse, who infiltrated the New Orleans Legal Assistance Corps, and outlines the Bureau's responses to inquiries about this situation from Congressman Charles E. Wiggins. Additional documents address the status of responses to Congressional requests and security clearances for Senate Select Committee staff.
title: FBI Responses to Congressional Committee Requests and Related Matters
recipient: Mr. J. B. Adams, Director, FBI, Honorable Charles E. Wiggins, USIB Ad Hoc Coordinating Group
sender: Legal Counsel, SAC Atlanta, Director FBI, DCI
